comments.commentBody: The constitution specifically leaves powers with the states which are not assigned to the federal government within the confines of that document. JE - Excellent points. Few Americans know that the way the 14th Amendment was passed after the Civil War was due to the requirement that the rebel states do so, or stay under military occupation by the Union Army.

To regain control of their state governments it was required by an Act of Congress that each rebel state must ratify the 14th Amendment. The link below is to the actual Congressional document stating this, from March 2, 1867. One wonders if the Amendment would pass today without similar inducement.

When We The People decided that the federal government would assume responsibility for overseeing the nation's natural resource, the education of our children, and the care of the elderly and the sick it was because the states had failed to do the tasks themselves.

The 14th Amendment. which defines all persons born in the United States as citizens, was passed following the Civil War for a good reason. We The People decided at the beginning of this nation that a primary purpose of government is to protect the rights of citizens. The 14th Amendment restates this as a primary role of the federal government because states had failed miserably at the task. Some states continue to fail their citizens.

Now we have radical Republicans advocating the repeal of this most important amendment and chattering on about the sovereignty of the states.

There is a reason we have a strong federal government. Republicans, ignorant of the historical realities that brought us to the government we have today, want to return to a time when the United States was a weak confederation of sovereign states. We have tried that and it failed. The Civil War should have settled this issue, yet some among us want to fight the battle again.

Didn't Mr. Romney pay attention when he took that required American history survey class as an undergraduate at BYU?

The Republicans are determined to make us repeat the mistakes of the past. We must go "Forward."

Yes, there are many good and responsible fathers in the world. I doubt the author would dispute you on that point. But the fact that women are, in general, better stewards of income from development projects is not the author's unsubstantiated opinion; it is simply borne out by the evidence. Experience from income generation & microfinance projects all over the world has shown, time and again, that women are more likely to use the money they generate and/or save on food, healthcare, and education for their families. There are always exceptions to the rule, of course, but in my experience and that of many, many others, women have shown themselves to be the more successful foci of such projects by far.

I also have to take issue with your second point. Grameen Bank is world famous for the astounding work it has done with (and for) the poor in Bangladesh, whereas the government of Bangladesh (not just the current one) has attempted many similar projects that have failed miserably, not least because of rampant corruption. "Government oversight" is not all it's cracked up to be, and clearly something about Grameen's model is working.

Don't discount these women because they are poor. "Uneducated farmers and laborers" are some of the most savvy and intelligent people I have ever encountered.

The 70s were the glory days of watching tennis, and what I grew up with. There were lots of characters back then, and they were fun to watch. I remember watching Michael Fisbach during qualifying matches after he became famous with the spaghetii racket, and he was always entertaining. He flip-flopped like a seal over the net during a tie-breaker with Peter Fleming (McEnroe's doubles partner) in a match, and lost the point because the ball that was sailing out and hadn't landed out before his body touched the net. Fisbach would leave a ton of sawdust on the baseline and the ball boys would have to sweep it up during every change over. The crowd would chant "Fiiiiish!!!" from the stands to root him on since he was a local Long Island boy. He'd spin around in disbelief after Fleming hit one of his rocket ace serves. The players were so much fun back then with personality. They may be better athletes today but they're not as much fun to watch, and the tournament itself has become too corporate and sterile.

Ken Burns or someone should make a documentary of the '77 Open, it would be great to have it as a memory.

My sentiments exactly.  I've never hunted, but when I was younger I enjoyed fishing.  I did the "humane" thing and threw back most of my catch.  Then one day I realized that I was deriving my pleasure from an activity that caused intense suffering.  I suppose you can argue whether or not the fish feels pain from a hook, but it certainly feels panic as its dragged on a line and lifted out of the water.  Thinking about that, I gave up fishing forever.  Why do we need to maim and torture animals for "sport"?

There are still people who are poor who fill their freezers every fall with food for the winter by hunting. I don't know that this is any worse than eating animals reared in cruelty and killed brutally that are sold in supermarkets.
Hunters who hunt because they enjoy killing also exist and are reprehensible. Hunt, if you must, but do it with respect for life and don't make a spectacle of it. And don't insist that you be allowed to use assault rifles to do it.

First, Dave: not all domestic meat production is impersonal. There are still many family farms. The animals are raised naturally, in family groups, and when you have helped birth an animal and held it to nurse, you will (I do) make sure it is killed quickly and painlessly with no idea what is happening to it. The customers for my goat meat and my neighbors' beef and pork _want_ to know.
But mainly this: hunting, my fanny. In an area where people flocked to gun shows in late .08 and '09 because "Obama's gonna come take away all your guns, better get'em while you can," hardly anyone hunts. More deer are killed on roads than by guns. The neighbor whose comment that was has not hunted in my 24 years here.
Everyone wants to talk guns, buy guns, compare guns, enjoy the paranoid fantasy of having an opportunity to use them and become a hero, and use gun control as one more pretext for their unease at seeing a black guy in the White House. No one wants to get up at 3 AM, walk any distance, get wet, cold or hungry, or sit still and silent for 4 to 6 hours.
I support hunting, enjoy deer meat, and for years have invited people to hunt this deer-beset 100 acres. No luck. Two neighbors who process deer reports that no one is hunting.
It's just like birth certificates and "socialism." One more cover.

Prof. Shaviro in the article by James Stewart in the NY Times explains a key problem with the artful and lawful tax dodging of Mr. Romney's trustee: the uberwealthy engage in transactions with little or no economic substance designed just for tax avoidance. There may be nothing legally wrong with pushing the envelope if one has the money to hire the best accountants and tax lawyers. But there is something wrong with a tax code that rewards transactions with no economic substance or purpose other than to avoid taxes.

Mr. Romney should step up to the plate, show some courage, decry these problems in the tax code and suggest positive, definitive reforms. Maybe that's not what a businessman does. But it is what someone who wants to be President of the United States does. Mr. Romney, stop hiding behind the law as it is and your Church, and act like the President of the United States and not the CEO of Bain Capital.

And turn over more tax returns so that everyone can get a good look at how unfair the tax code really is.

I don't agree with the answer to #1: the problem with line-cutters is that they bump everyone behind them further back in the line, and make the process longer.  Everyone behind them loses ground.  In the situation described, the people with numbers 6 through (n) are not any more inconvenienced than they were when they arrived: the line is exactly as long as it was before the woman traded her number to a man near the end, and they lose nothing by the transaction.  That they did not *gain* anything (i.e. a bump *up* in line due to her absence) by the woman leaving is kind of a bummer for them I guess, but I don't think its the problem of the person who got the windfall of what is essentially a lucky lottery ticket.

Not "obviously not". If she offered the place line, then left, how are the people behind her hurt? If someone substituted for another person in line, I would not think a thing about it, because I would not feel "entitled" to receive the chance to move up because someone stepped out. My position would not be changed.

One way to make the line-jumping quandary easier: Would you have done it if the woman had offered you her physical location in line?  Obviously not, amid disapproving glances (or worse) from other patrons.  But taking the number accomplished the same thing.

Bob, the idea of giving out numbers for service means 'first come, first served'. How about if five people ahead of you decided to leave and gave their numbers to the next five people to walk in the door? Wouldn't you feel you were 'next'? You would and you'd be right.

Ethics is a matter of right or wrong. It doesn't need to be a life and death situation. Paying someone to stand in line for you is sort of like ticket-scalping. It may be a simple business transaction between you and the person you pay to wait but it is at the expense of everyone else in line.

Paying someone to mow your lawn is a business transaction, too. But it doesn't involve anyone else. No one else will be denied the opportunity to mow their own lawn because you paid someone to do your work. It just isn't the same thing - ethics doesn't enter into it. (Unless you're underpaying your lawn worker because they are an undocumented worker and you know you will get away with exploiting them. In that case, you're being unethical and breaking several laws. But that's a different story.)

The first question does not have anything to do with ethics: it is only about etiquette and it is culturally dependent. In many countries where The Line doesn't hold the sacred status that it holds for Americans, no one would worry about this at all. In fact, in some places there are even people who turn this into a free market by standing in line for you and selling you the ticket! It may offend some sensibilities, but is it unethical? I don't think so. Why can you pay someone to spend time mowing your lawn but not standing in line for you? It doesn't make any sense.
RE: LW1. Please see Kyralessa below - that clears it up for me.

I don't entirely agree with the Ethicist's answer to #1. Taking the woman's number is not clear-cut line cutting - the letter writer did not insert herself in the line, therefore bumping everyone behind her back one place. She merely substituted herself for the woman who was leaving. Imagine the letter writer's original number was 27 and her new number was 15. Nothing had changed for those with numbers 16-26. However, those with numbers 28 and up would all move up one position, as the LW would have already left and not replied to the call for her number. As I see it, it's basically a wash - the line was shortened at some point due to the woman's leaving and the LW taking her spot. Whether this occurs for #16 or #28 really doesn't make a difference. Take the number, consider yourself lucky, and, perhaps, try to pay it forward at some point.

As for question #2, I wholeheartedly disagree with the Ethicist. The co-worker should absolutely pay the $30 fine and not expense it. The only reason she considered expensing it is because it was attached to the rental car receipt (a detail which I find dubious at best) and she felt no one would notice. However, if she got a parking ticket, mailed to her at a later date, would she try to expense that? Of course not. In my mind, the answer to this is so obvious that I find it hard to believe that this letter was chosen for publication.

Disagree with you, jad. Every person in line behind Lady Who Left (LWL) up to, but not including, the Letter Writer (Man Who Cut) had to wait for 1 extra person to be served- MWC, because he jumped ahead of them by taking the place of someone who left the line. No customer behind MWC, in his original place in line, was forced to wait longer. So MWC got a benefit over all those who were waiting ahead of him, except those 4 ahead of LWL. On the EZpass-- I've never had the pleasure of doing anything on an expense account. Aren't there usually company rules about what is covered and what isn't? Dinner up to $X, yes; dinner companion (ex: prostitute), no? Rental car, yes; speeding ticket, no? Seems like the ethical issue is not whether she should slip the charge in, in the hopes that it is not spotted & possibly rejected, but whether she should submit it, point it out to her boss/auditor, and let them decide whether it is a charge they believe is a proper travel expense? And IF she thinks it is legit, and they reject it, then appeal it.

Typically the bounce arises from movements among nonpartisans who have yet to make up their minds. Each candidate gets an above-average dose of media coverage, often without much competing coverage of the other candidate. Traditionally the candidate whose party is not holding the convention tends to lay low.

This year, however, it seems likely that any bounce will be fairly limited because there are so few undecided voters. If 2012 turns out to be a "base" election, as many pundits have predicted, then the number of undecided voters who might be swayed by events like conventions is small. Looking at the most recent national polls at RCP shows about 9% undecideds. At least a third or maybe even half of those people will not be voting in November. So that leaves us with perhaps 4-5% of the electorate who might be swayed by campaign events. Even if they break 60-40 for one candidate or the other, the next effect is just 1% of the total vote.
